HOW THE WEATHER 15 MADE.

In order to intelligently predict the coming
weather for even a small section of the country,
it is necessary to know the weather conditions
that exist simultaneously over a large part of
the country at the time, especially over the
sections to the west of the place for which the
predktion is to be made, as the weather of a
place depends upon the atmospheric conditions
developed to the west of it.
To guide the forecaster at Baltimore in making predictions, telegraphic reports of weather
elements are received at the station twice a
day from about 110 stations scattered throughout the United States and Canada. These telegraphic reports are the results of simultaneous
observations made at these various stations at
8 A. M. and 8 P. m., respectively. The information they give is : Pressure of the air for
each station, reduced to sea level and a standard temperature of 32 degrees ; temperature
of the air ; wet bulb temperature ; the precipitation ; wind movement and direction ;
clouds (the amount and direction) ; the maximum wind velocity and direction in the past
twenty-four hours, and the time of beginning
and ending of thunder-storms. These telegrams are all sent in cipher. The following is
an example of a message that was sent from
Baltimore this morning (January 30) at 8 A.M.
BALTIMORE B URDEN FUNDABLE ENDANGER
FOG. Translated, this means that the report
was from Baltimore, given with the first word;
that the barometer was 30.10 inches and the
temperature 24, given in the second word; the
wind cast, the weather clear, and the wet bulb
thermometer 22, given in the third word; the
fourth shows that the wind was light and that
the minimum temperature during the night
was 24 degrees, and the last word that there
was a light fog. It is also shown in this
telegram that no rain fell within the twenty-

No. 10

four hours from 8 A. M. of the 29th to 8 P. M.
of the 30th, by the absence of a word beginning
with H or L in the third place. Among the
reports received this morning is the following
from Chicago: BETON Y HUZZAING SEXTON
DETONATE KEYHOLE, which, translated, means
that the barometer was 30.14; the temperature
2 degrees below zero; the wet thermometer 2
degrees below zero; the wind velocity 24 miles
an hour, and the rise in pressure for two hours
preceding observation .o8 of an inch. These
are given to illustrate the completeness of the
code and to show the accuracy with which observations may be transmitted by means of it.
At 7.40 o'clock (75th meridian time) each
morning and evening the observers at the different stations begin taking their observations
from accurately tested and standardized instruments, noting all the elementary conditions of
the air, such as pressure, temperature, wind

as it may require. As fast as the reports come
in over the wires, they are quickly delivered.

places, respectively. The barometer, temperature and other data, which are represented by
figures, arc written near the places so reporting; while by the use of symbols, with arrows
to show the direction of the wind, the other
weather elements, such as clear, cloudy, rain,

and measures which have made the institution.
One passage delineated the characteristics of
three of the first professors, now deceased—
Sylvester, Martin and Morris—and this was
accompanied by cordial tributes to Professors
Gildersleeve, Remsen and Rowland—three survivors of the original staff.
After the address the following candidates
were admitted to degrees, viz: To the degree
of bachelor of arts—Albert C. Dieffenbach.
Leonard K. Hirshberg, Powhatan J. Wooldridge. To the degree of doctor of philosophy—James R. Ewing, A. B.; George P.
Krapp, A. B.; Walter A. Montgomery, A. B.;
Mervin T. Sudler, S. B.
Two portraits were next presented to the
University. That of Professor Sylvester, the
mathematician, painted in his red Oxford
robes, by Harper Pennington, is the gift of an
individual admirer of Dr. Sylvester. That of
Professor Remsen, painted by Robert G.
1fardie, is the gift of former students of chemistry and a few personal friends. The establishment of a Sylvester medal for excellence in
mathematics was also announced, as well as
some other generous gifts.
An enjoyable feature of the celebration was
the music by the Hopkins musical societies,
under the general leadership of Mr. E. L.
Turnbull, B. A. of 1893.
A GRADUATES CLUB.

At the alumni dinner at Rennert's last evening Professor Adams made an appeal for the
institution of a graduates' club, strictly limited
to Hopkins alumni and graduate students connected with the University. He suggested the
idea of an open fraternity, embracing the
younger members of the faculty and resident
graduates—in short, a larger, more democratic
society, into which Hopkins collegians can be
elected after receiving the degree of A. B. The
present University Club in Baltimore is not
primarily a Hopkins club. The graduates of
any institution can join it. Indeed, it is not

3

restricted to college men. There is need of a
kind of junior university club, which shall
afford a bond of union between graduate students and citizen graduates. The young men
who have gone forth from the Johns Hopkins
into business iii Baltimore, into the liberal professions, into journalism and teaching, are
really the largest and most influential of Hopkins graduate departments. The alumni should
make common cause for good government,
sound learning, and good fellowship with all
Hopkinsians.
Dr. Adams described the so-called Graduates' Club of Yale University. An old house
facing New Haven Green has been fitted up
in most attractive fashion with historic furniture, portraits, water colors, bric-a-brac, and
college souvenirs. The building in its interior
appointments represents not only young Yale,
but also an old Yale environment. There is a
front parlor on the second floor, combining the
best features of a club reading-room, an artists'
studio and a college student's room, with cushioned window seats. On the ground floor there
is a dining-room where members can enjoy a
table d'hote dinner at a fixed price. Some of
the best features of the old Johns Hopkins Club
which flourished for ten years in two rooms
near the University are to be found in the
Graduates' Club at New Haven, but the setting
is much more artistic and pleasing to the eye.
Such an institution could easily be reproduced
in Baltimore. A convenient clubhouse near
the University can be found and the rental can
be defrayed by regular lodgers in the upper
rooms, as in New Haven or in the fraternity
houses in this city. The annual dues from
alumni and graduates should be very moderate—perhaps $5 a year, with an initiation
fee from permanent members. Voluntary subscriptions, with the initiation fees, would perhaps serve to furnish the clubhouse. It was
suggested that committees be immediately appointed to secure the co-operation of resident
alumni and resident graduates in this -project
for a Johns Hopkins Graduate Club.

WIIEN the spiriting away of a junior by the
freshmen last year, at the time of the junior
banquet, was made the subject of a highly distorted and damaging article in a morning paper,
and at a season when the University was making its best bow before the Legislature, the faculty took a resolute stand and said,"kidnapping
must go." It has gone. To the credit of
the undergraduates, we believe their peaceable
attitude was due to an appreciation of the position of the University rather than from any
"fear of the law." Johns Hopkins has always
allowed its students the widest freedom, a liberty they have never abused. When the faculty
was persuaded that kidnapping was so hurtful
to the interests of the University as to make a
proclamation on the subject necessary, the
undergraduates showed their loyalty and their
good sense by putting an end to the practice.

NOTWITHSTANDING the appropriation of the
rental from lockers for the purposes of the
Athletic Association, amounting to about one
thousand dollars annually, resources undreamed of in other years, the expenses of the
teams has so rapidly increased with their expanding importance that the Board of the As-

sociation at a late meeting was seriously debating the necessity of dropping one of the sports.
Appropriations were cut down instead. This
was so disappointing to the management of
the track team that the captain and the manager resigned; the amount appropriated they
deemed quite inadequate to complete the season on the progressive lines projected.
The important question of the policy Johns
Hopkins is to pursue in athletics is opened
up. It is contended, on the one hand, that
the number of teams should be reduced; that
the larger funds available for the remaining
teams would permit of their more perfect development, and wider participation in athletic
events, especially among the larger colleges;
that only in this way will it be possible for
Hopkins to gain any prominence in athletics.
From another point of view, the end of our
athletics is not so much to win prestige and
glory as to give to the greatest possible number
the pleasure 'and profit that a diversity of
sports—within due limits—will afford, and especially where teams may be put on the field
that will bring no discredit to the University.
Again, it is held that Hopkins by the very numr,
her of our students is limited in athletic possibilities, that we cannot hope to very widely extend our field; to cut off one team for the
benefit of another tinder such circumstances
would be manifestly unfair.
The Athletic Association must eventually
refer the whole matter to the student body.
THE NEWS-LETTER does not at this time advocate one policy or another. We do advocate a
full and free discussion of the subject. Our
columns are open for the purpose. Is it necessary to drop any of our teams ? If so, which ?
If we are to widen our athletic horizon, in what
direction ? The discussion must be based on
present conditions and resources. It must be
practical. We make but one stipulation: Correspondents must keep within the limits of 300
words. It is time now for all jealousies to be
laid aside, and a clear and definite policy shaped
for Hopkins athletics, on which we may unite.

The class banquets are over and gone. The
freshmen, notwithstanding the peaceable protestations of the juniors, fearing lest at the
eleventh hour they should be hoodwinked by
the cunning wiles of the devil and the upperclassmen, banded together in groups of ten
for mutual protection, found their way to The
Carrollton under the secrecy afforded by dark
and devious alleys. The menu provided a significantly appropriate course in "Clear Green
turtle." They had lots of other good things
to eat, and made merry on the Roman punch
and champagne sauce, the whole concluding_
with coffee and cigarettes. (And so young I )
The toasts, happily arranged, were introduced
with facetious quotations, to wit: "The Faculty and Freshmen," " To compare great
things with small," responded to by John
Gresham Machen. "The Loyalty of 1901,"
by Swindell, and "Our Freshman Orators,"
by Briscoe, were notable contributions. John
Manning Booker was toast-master. The menu
cards were tastily gotten up, decorated with
pen-and-ink sketches by Swindell and Duck.
In the list of officers printed on the cards
Naughty-One exhibits everything from a president to an orator, and a" Delegate to the Matriculate Society"! Naughty-One is all right.
Not having the freshmen to contend with,
the juniors, on the evening of their banquet,
battled with the blizzard. When they reached
the Hotel Rennert they wanted to battle with
the proprietor. It was a memorable Monday
night. Those twenty juniors had come a long
way; they had ploughed through snowdrifts up
to their necks; they were cold, and they were
hungry. Ye Gods! What was this ? The
proprietor of this respectable hotel had never
so much as heard of a Junior Banquet I He
placidly regretted the circumstances, but it
would be impossible to entertain the company.
The steward, with whom the committee had
treated, was ill and could not be produced.

5

The committee expostulated, they damned, they
grew red in the face by turns, but to no avail.
Had they not in person arranged the menu
with the steward, ordered covers for thirty-five,
and that very afternoon received confirming
word by telephone ? Well, the committee had
no other resort than to wipe their feet on the
hotel mat, and hasten down to Father Shannon
at The Carrollton. A hungry junior, as he
went glowering through the lobby, was thus
said to have laconically summed up the situation : "Rennert, Rot." In an hour the
disappointed juniors sat down to a dinner,
which, if it was short the terrapin and duck the
original bill-of-lading called for, in the way of
solid comfort was not to be surpassed. James
L. A. Burrell touched off the speakers, and the
toasts were one long and beautiful pyrotechnic
display. The bill for broken dishes was $6.75.

THE MUSICAL CLUBS.

Within a few weeks the Glee, Banjo and
Mandolin Clubs are to give concerts at BrynMawr and Wilmington. Last year was the
fi'rst time that the clubs played at Bryn-Mawr,
and they were greeted by a large and enthusiastic audience. Even a more cordial reception
is assured this year. It has always been customary for the clubs to give a concert during
Easter week at Old Point. This season they
will play there on the evening of Easter Monday, at the Hotel Hygeia.
Perhaps the most enjoyable concert of last
year's trip was that given at Richmond. The
clubs were received with true Virginian hospitality, and they look forward with much
pleasure to their coming concert there. Norfolk will probably be visited, and arrangements
are being made for a concert at Charlottesville.
Contrary to their usual custom, the clubs will
give a concert this spring after Easter, in
Washington, early in April, for charity. There
also is a possibility that the clubs may be heard
again in Baltimore before Easter in connection
with some local charity.

POINTS ON ATHLETICS.

THE NEWS-LETTER,
It is doubtful if any one particular feature
of the game is more important than passing—
certainly none is more.difficult. Every lacrosse
Player learns to catch with proficiency, but comparatively few pass well. Always pass on
the run, and in front of the man who is to receive the ball. There is no. better way to practice this than for two men to run up and down
the field passing to each other. Make your
passes quick and snappy, always passing from
the body or baggy part of your stick.

JOHN P. CURRY.

413o0ofp of tpe common
Those wlio deplore the fact that the resources
of the Athletic Association are at low ebb will
do well to interest themselves, and heartily, in
the approaching indoor exhibition in the gymnasium. The proceeds of the event will be
handed over to the Association. In other years
substantial sums have been realized from similar exhibitions. "Colonel" Crenshaw is sparing no pains to make the evening full of
interest.

.38 .3$
The Dean's stern hand of justice threatens to
have a somewhat disastrous effect upon some
of our college organizations, for the rule lately
passed limiting participants in athletics and
the musical clubs to students with averages of
2,1 or over has already nipped in the bud some
very promising young men. The athletic
teams will suffer particularly on this account
unless the unfortunates can succeed in "boning
up" sufficiently to ward off the evil day. Let
us hope that scholarship and athletics can both
reign, and that neither will have to be sacrificed for the other.
.s$
Mr. John P. Curry, who contributes the article on Lacrosse, needs no introduction to Hopkins athletes. A niember of the crack lacrosse
team of the Crescent Athletic Club, Brooklyn,

7

he speaks from a wide knowledge of the game.
His coaching of our team last year helped it a
long way toward the championship. In our
next issue Mr. W. H. Mackdermott will contribute an article on Starting, for runners, giving hints of greatest value to the novice. The
man who "knows it all" may also "run and
read" with profit. This series of articles—
Points on Athletics—is well worth preserving,
offering as it does a large amount of practical
suggestion, written from the experience of
men—specialists in their line.

It may be a matter of congratulation that
baseball was not dropped from the list of sports
this spring, for, in the opinion of Leon L. Joyner, captain of the team, the University has
better prospects of making a good showing
than at any time within the past three or four
years. When the first call for candidates was
made, it was announced that pitchers and catchers were particularly needed. Lack of an efficient battery has, in fact, been our chief weakness for a long time; but, among the candidates
who offered themselves, have been found several pitchers, who bid fair to be very valuable.
Catchers, too, have been found, and the team
can be practically completed with the exception
of the outfield, which is, as yet, an unknown
quantity. The pitching staff will include
Frazer, a new man from Kentucky; Radcliffe,
who made a brilliant record at the University
of Pennsylvania; and Strouse, a sub-freshman.
Radcliffe is also an excellent catcher, and, together with Constantine and Miller, of the
freshman class, will hold up that end of the battery. The bases will be filled by the old reliables—Joyner, Clark and Wirt—and Miller will
also have a strong claim on short-stop. The
outfield will be selected later from the remaining candidates. Among the other men who are
showing up in good form are White, a medical
man, who has come lately from Leland Stanfor University, where he played centre-field:
Griffin, Briscoe, Smith and Swindell.

The class for the study of public aid to the
poor, charities and correction, which is conducted by Dr. Brackett, will visit the Bayview
Asylum on Friday, February 24, in order to
investigate the organization and condition of
the city almshouse.
JI

Professor Adams yesterday afternoon gave
an historical address in the parlor of the Carrollton Hotel before the Colonial Dames of
America, on the occasion of their unveiling an
historical tablet commemorating three visits
of General Washington to Baltimore.
J4

Mr. P. L. Groome, of the Historical Department, delivered a lecture last week before the
students of the Western Maryland College, in
which he especially emphasized the duty of
the scholar toward the vital problems of social
and national life.
A party of juniors went to Washington last
Tuesday, under the auspices of the University,
to attend a session of Congress. The trip was
suggested by President Gilman at a recent
meeting of the House of Representatives. The
President expressed great delight in the progress the junior class had made in parliamentary
practice, and then proposed the pilgrimage to
the Capitol.
.0 .A1

Dr. William Newton Clarke, D. D., Professor
of Christian Theology in Colgate University,
will deliver a course of three lectures on this
foundation during the month of March. His
subjects will be: The Christian People, The
Christian Doctrine, The Christian Power. Dr.
Clarke is well known as the author of a book
on Systematic Theology, and enjoys a high reputation as a scholar and writer.

has been compelled to resign from the junior
debating team, of which he was chairman. His
place has been filled by E. P. Hyde. The final

selected. They are as follows, the three last

Jones, King, Greenbaum and Reymann. Juniors—Messrs. Hyde, Liddell, Lindheim, Hill,
Beeuwkes, Griffin, McAll, Foster and Greene.

HOW THE WEATHER 15 MADE.

In order to intelligently predict the coming
weather for even a small section of the country,
it is necessary to know the weather conditions
that exist simultaneously over a large part of
the country at the time, especially over the
sections to the west of the place for which the
predktion is to be made, as the weather of a
place depends upon the atmospheric conditions
developed to the west of it.
To guide the forecaster at Baltimore in making predictions, telegraphic reports of weather
elements are received at the station twice a
day from about 110 stations scattered throughout the United States and Canada. These telegraphic reports are the results of simultaneous
observations made at these various stations at
8 A. M. and 8 P. m., respectively. The information they give is : Pressure of the air for
each station, reduced to sea level and a standard temperature of 32 degrees ; temperature
of the air ; wet bulb temperature ; the precipitation ; wind movement and direction ;
clouds (the amount and direction) ; the maximum wind velocity and direction in the past
twenty-four hours, and the time of beginning
and ending of thunder-storms. These telegrams are all sent in cipher. The following is
an example of a message that was sent from
Baltimore this morning (January 30) at 8 A.M.
BALTIMORE B URDEN FUNDABLE ENDANGER
FOG. Translated, this means that the report
was from Baltimore, given with the first word;
that the barometer was 30.10 inches and the
temperature 24, given in the second word; the
wind cast, the weather clear, and the wet bulb
thermometer 22, given in the third word; the
fourth shows that the wind was light and that
the minimum temperature during the night
was 24 degrees, and the last word that there
was a light fog. It is also shown in this
telegram that no rain fell within the twenty-

No. 10

four hours from 8 A. M. of the 29th to 8 P. M.
of the 30th, by the absence of a word beginning
with H or L in the third place. Among the
reports received this morning is the following
from Chicago: BETON Y HUZZAING SEXTON
DETONATE KEYHOLE, which, translated, means
that the barometer was 30.14; the temperature
2 degrees below zero; the wet thermometer 2
degrees below zero; the wind velocity 24 miles
an hour, and the rise in pressure for two hours
preceding observation .o8 of an inch. These
are given to illustrate the completeness of the
code and to show the accuracy with which observations may be transmitted by means of it.
At 7.40 o'clock (75th meridian time) each
morning and evening the observers at the different stations begin taking their observations
from accurately tested and standardized instruments, noting all the elementary conditions of
the air, such as pressure, temperature, wind
By 8
velocity and direction, rainfall, etc.
o'clock the necessary mathematical corrections
have been made, all observations reduced to the
cipher, and each filed at the local telegraph
office. During the next thirty or forty minutes
these telegrams, with the right of way over all
lines, are hurrying to their destinations, each
station contributing its own observations and
receiving in return, by systematic telegraphic
circuits, such observations from other stations
as it may require. As fast as the reports come
in over the wires, they are quickly delivered.
and the cipher translated into figures and
words of intelligible order.
The weather conditions given are then entered on a geographical map at the different
places, respectively. The barometer, temperature and other data, which are represented by
figures, arc written near the places so reporting; while by the use of symbols, with arrows
to show the direction of the wind, the other
weather elements, such as clear, cloudy, rain,

2

etc., are shown. Blue pencil lines are then gion or on the Pacific coast or in the far Northdrawn through points having the same atmos- west, and their final destination the Gulf of St.

One passage delineated the characteristics of
three of the first professors, now deceased—
Sylvester, Martin and Morris—and this was
accompanied by cordial tributes to Professors
Gildersleeve, Remsen and Rowland—three survivors of the original staff.
After the address the following candidates
were admitted to degrees, viz: To the degree
of bachelor of arts—Albert C. Dieffenbach.
Leonard K. Hirshberg, Powhatan J. Wooldridge. To the degree of doctor of philosophy—James R. Ewing, A. B.; George P.
Krapp, A. B.; Walter A. Montgomery, A. B.;
Mervin T. Sudler, S. B.
Two portraits were next presented to the
University. That of Professor Sylvester, the
mathematician, painted in his red Oxford
robes, by Harper Pennington, is the gift of an
individual admirer of Dr. Sylvester. That of
Professor Remsen, painted by Robert G.
1fardie, is the gift of former students of chemistry and a few personal friends. The establishment of a Sylvester medal for excellence in
mathematics was also announced, as well as
some other generous gifts.
An enjoyable feature of the celebration was
the music by the Hopkins musical societies,
under the general leadership of Mr. E. L.
Turnbull, B. A. of 1893.
A GRADUATES CLUB.

At the alumni dinner at Rennert's last evening Professor Adams made an appeal for the
institution of a graduates' club, strictly limited
to Hopkins alumni and graduate students connected with the University. He suggested the
idea of an open fraternity, embracing the
younger members of the faculty and resident
graduates—in short, a larger, more democratic
society, into which Hopkins collegians can be
elected after receiving the degree of A. B. The
present University Club in Baltimore is not
primarily a Hopkins club. The graduates of
any institution can join it. Indeed, it is not

3

restricted to college men. There is need of a
kind of junior university club, which shall
afford a bond of union between graduate students and citizen graduates. The young men
who have gone forth from the Johns Hopkins
into business iii Baltimore, into the liberal professions, into journalism and teaching, are
really the largest and most influential of Hopkins graduate departments. The alumni should
make common cause for good government,
sound learning, and good fellowship with all
Hopkinsians.
Dr. Adams described the so-called Graduates' Club of Yale University. An old house
facing New Haven Green has been fitted up
in most attractive fashion with historic furniture, portraits, water colors, bric-a-brac, and
college souvenirs. The building in its interior
appointments represents not only young Yale,
but also an old Yale environment. There is a
front parlor on the second floor, combining the
best features of a club reading-room, an artists'
studio and a college student's room, with cushioned window seats. On the ground floor there
is a dining-room where members can enjoy a
table d'hote dinner at a fixed price. Some of
the best features of the old Johns Hopkins Club
which flourished for ten years in two rooms
near the University are to be found in the
Graduates' Club at New Haven, but the setting
is much more artistic and pleasing to the eye.
Such an institution could easily be reproduced
in Baltimore. A convenient clubhouse near
the University can be found and the rental can
be defrayed by regular lodgers in the upper
rooms, as in New Haven or in the fraternity
houses in this city. The annual dues from
alumni and graduates should be very moderate—perhaps $5 a year, with an initiation
fee from permanent members. Voluntary subscriptions, with the initiation fees, would perhaps serve to furnish the clubhouse. It was
suggested that committees be immediately appointed to secure the co-operation of resident
alumni and resident graduates in this -project
for a Johns Hopkins Graduate Club.

WIIEN the spiriting away of a junior by the
freshmen last year, at the time of the junior
banquet, was made the subject of a highly distorted and damaging article in a morning paper,
and at a season when the University was making its best bow before the Legislature, the faculty took a resolute stand and said,"kidnapping
must go." It has gone. To the credit of
the undergraduates, we believe their peaceable
attitude was due to an appreciation of the position of the University rather than from any
"fear of the law." Johns Hopkins has always
allowed its students the widest freedom, a liberty they have never abused. When the faculty
was persuaded that kidnapping was so hurtful
to the interests of the University as to make a
proclamation on the subject necessary, the
undergraduates showed their loyalty and their
good sense by putting an end to the practice.

NOTWITHSTANDING the appropriation of the
rental from lockers for the purposes of the
Athletic Association, amounting to about one
thousand dollars annually, resources undreamed of in other years, the expenses of the
teams has so rapidly increased with their expanding importance that the Board of the As-

sociation at a late meeting was seriously debating the necessity of dropping one of the sports.
Appropriations were cut down instead. This
was so disappointing to the management of
the track team that the captain and the manager resigned; the amount appropriated they
deemed quite inadequate to complete the season on the progressive lines projected.
The important question of the policy Johns
Hopkins is to pursue in athletics is opened
up. It is contended, on the one hand, that
the number of teams should be reduced; that
the larger funds available for the remaining
teams would permit of their more perfect development, and wider participation in athletic
events, especially among the larger colleges;
that only in this way will it be possible for
Hopkins to gain any prominence in athletics.
From another point of view, the end of our
athletics is not so much to win prestige and
glory as to give to the greatest possible number
the pleasure 'and profit that a diversity of
sports—within due limits—will afford, and especially where teams may be put on the field
that will bring no discredit to the University.
Again, it is held that Hopkins by the very numr,
her of our students is limited in athletic possibilities, that we cannot hope to very widely extend our field; to cut off one team for the
benefit of another tinder such circumstances
would be manifestly unfair.
The Athletic Association must eventually
refer the whole matter to the student body.
THE NEWS-LETTER does not at this time advocate one policy or another. We do advocate a
full and free discussion of the subject. Our
columns are open for the purpose. Is it necessary to drop any of our teams ? If so, which ?
If we are to widen our athletic horizon, in what
direction ? The discussion must be based on
present conditions and resources. It must be
practical. We make but one stipulation: Correspondents must keep within the limits of 300
words. It is time now for all jealousies to be
laid aside, and a clear and definite policy shaped
for Hopkins athletics, on which we may unite.

The class banquets are over and gone. The
freshmen, notwithstanding the peaceable protestations of the juniors, fearing lest at the
eleventh hour they should be hoodwinked by
the cunning wiles of the devil and the upperclassmen, banded together in groups of ten
for mutual protection, found their way to The
Carrollton under the secrecy afforded by dark
and devious alleys. The menu provided a significantly appropriate course in "Clear Green
turtle." They had lots of other good things
to eat, and made merry on the Roman punch
and champagne sauce, the whole concluding_
with coffee and cigarettes. (And so young I )
The toasts, happily arranged, were introduced
with facetious quotations, to wit: "The Faculty and Freshmen," " To compare great
things with small," responded to by John
Gresham Machen. "The Loyalty of 1901,"
by Swindell, and "Our Freshman Orators,"
by Briscoe, were notable contributions. John
Manning Booker was toast-master. The menu
cards were tastily gotten up, decorated with
pen-and-ink sketches by Swindell and Duck.
In the list of officers printed on the cards
Naughty-One exhibits everything from a president to an orator, and a" Delegate to the Matriculate Society"! Naughty-One is all right.
Not having the freshmen to contend with,
the juniors, on the evening of their banquet,
battled with the blizzard. When they reached
the Hotel Rennert they wanted to battle with
the proprietor. It was a memorable Monday
night. Those twenty juniors had come a long
way; they had ploughed through snowdrifts up
to their necks; they were cold, and they were
hungry. Ye Gods! What was this ? The
proprietor of this respectable hotel had never
so much as heard of a Junior Banquet I He
placidly regretted the circumstances, but it
would be impossible to entertain the company.
The steward, with whom the committee had
treated, was ill and could not be produced.

5

The committee expostulated, they damned, they
grew red in the face by turns, but to no avail.
Had they not in person arranged the menu
with the steward, ordered covers for thirty-five,
and that very afternoon received confirming
word by telephone ? Well, the committee had
no other resort than to wipe their feet on the
hotel mat, and hasten down to Father Shannon
at The Carrollton. A hungry junior, as he
went glowering through the lobby, was thus
said to have laconically summed up the situation : "Rennert, Rot." In an hour the
disappointed juniors sat down to a dinner,
which, if it was short the terrapin and duck the
original bill-of-lading called for, in the way of
solid comfort was not to be surpassed. James
L. A. Burrell touched off the speakers, and the
toasts were one long and beautiful pyrotechnic
display. The bill for broken dishes was $6.75.

THE MUSICAL CLUBS.

Within a few weeks the Glee, Banjo and
Mandolin Clubs are to give concerts at BrynMawr and Wilmington. Last year was the
fi'rst time that the clubs played at Bryn-Mawr,
and they were greeted by a large and enthusiastic audience. Even a more cordial reception
is assured this year. It has always been customary for the clubs to give a concert during
Easter week at Old Point. This season they
will play there on the evening of Easter Monday, at the Hotel Hygeia.
Perhaps the most enjoyable concert of last
year's trip was that given at Richmond. The
clubs were received with true Virginian hospitality, and they look forward with much
pleasure to their coming concert there. Norfolk will probably be visited, and arrangements
are being made for a concert at Charlottesville.
Contrary to their usual custom, the clubs will
give a concert this spring after Easter, in
Washington, early in April, for charity. There
also is a possibility that the clubs may be heard
again in Baltimore before Easter in connection
with some local charity.

POINTS ON ATHLETICS.

THE NEWS-LETTER,
It is doubtful if any one particular feature
of the game is more important than passing—
certainly none is more.difficult. Every lacrosse
Player learns to catch with proficiency, but comparatively few pass well. Always pass on
the run, and in front of the man who is to receive the ball. There is no. better way to practice this than for two men to run up and down
the field passing to each other. Make your
passes quick and snappy, always passing from
the body or baggy part of your stick.

JOHN P. CURRY.

Those wlio deplore the fact that the resources
of the Athletic Association are at low ebb will
do well to interest themselves, and heartily, in
the approaching indoor exhibition in the gymnasium. The proceeds of the event will be
handed over to the Association. In other years
substantial sums have been realized from similar exhibitions. "Colonel" Crenshaw is sparing no pains to make the evening full of
interest.

.38 .3$
The Dean's stern hand of justice threatens to
have a somewhat disastrous effect upon some
of our college organizations, for the rule lately
passed limiting participants in athletics and
the musical clubs to students with averages of
2,1 or over has already nipped in the bud some
very promising young men. The athletic
teams will suffer particularly on this account
unless the unfortunates can succeed in "boning
up" sufficiently to ward off the evil day. Let
us hope that scholarship and athletics can both
reign, and that neither will have to be sacrificed for the other.

Mr. John P. Curry, who contributes the article on Lacrosse, needs no introduction to Hopkins athletes. A niember of the crack lacrosse
team of the Crescent Athletic Club, Brooklyn,

7

he speaks from a wide knowledge of the game.
His coaching of our team last year helped it a
long way toward the championship. In our
next issue Mr. W. H. Mackdermott will contribute an article on Starting, for runners, giving hints of greatest value to the novice. The
man who "knows it all" may also "run and
read" with profit. This series of articles—
Points on Athletics—is well worth preserving,
offering as it does a large amount of practical
suggestion, written from the experience of
men—specialists in their line.

It may be a matter of congratulation that
baseball was not dropped from the list of sports
this spring, for, in the opinion of Leon L. Joyner, captain of the team, the University has
better prospects of making a good showing
than at any time within the past three or four
years. When the first call for candidates was
made, it was announced that pitchers and catchers were particularly needed. Lack of an efficient battery has, in fact, been our chief weakness for a long time; but, among the candidates
who offered themselves, have been found several pitchers, who bid fair to be very valuable.
Catchers, too, have been found, and the team
can be practically completed with the exception
of the outfield, which is, as yet, an unknown
quantity. The pitching staff will include
Frazer, a new man from Kentucky; Radcliffe,
who made a brilliant record at the University
of Pennsylvania; and Strouse, a sub-freshman.
Radcliffe is also an excellent catcher, and, together with Constantine and Miller, of the
freshman class, will hold up that end of the battery. The bases will be filled by the old reliables—Joyner, Clark and Wirt—and Miller will
also have a strong claim on short-stop. The
outfield will be selected later from the remaining candidates. Among the other men who are
showing up in good form are White, a medical
man, who has come lately from Leland Stanfor University, where he played centre-field:
Griffin, Briscoe, Smith and Swindell.

The class for the study of public aid to the
poor, charities and correction, which is conducted by Dr. Brackett, will visit the Bayview
Asylum on Friday, February 24, in order to
investigate the organization and condition of
the city almshouse.

Professor Adams yesterday afternoon gave
an historical address in the parlor of the Carrollton Hotel before the Colonial Dames of
America, on the occasion of their unveiling an
historical tablet commemorating three visits
of General Washington to Baltimore.
J4

Mr. P. L. Groome, of the Historical Department, delivered a lecture last week before the
students of the Western Maryland College, in
which he especially emphasized the duty of
the scholar toward the vital problems of social
and national life.
A party of juniors went to Washington last
Tuesday, under the auspices of the University,
to attend a session of Congress. The trip was
suggested by President Gilman at a recent
meeting of the House of Representatives. The
President expressed great delight in the progress the junior class had made in parliamentary
practice, and then proposed the pilgrimage to
the Capitol.

Dr. William Newton Clarke, D. D., Professor
of Christian Theology in Colgate University,
will deliver a course of three lectures on this
foundation during the month of March. His
subjects will be: The Christian People, The
Christian Doctrine, The Christian Power. Dr.
Clarke is well known as the author of a book
on Systematic Theology, and enjoys a high reputation as a scholar and writer.

Beeuwkes, Griffin, McAll, Foster and Greene.
